title: Paniagua Coffee brand Font ID
content:
Trying to figure out what this font type is. Thanks in advance

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Paniagua_4016.png)
author: eerroognp

comments.content: No perfect match unfortunately, may be custom? Alternatives: [Gaz](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typodermic/gaz), [Bourgeois](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/virusfonts/bourgeois) Condensed Bold, [Refrigerator Deluxe](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/marksimonson/refrigerator-deluxe) Bold, [Agency](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.myfonts.com/search/Agency), [Duke](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.losttype.com/duke) Fill

I agree that it is probably custom. The PANIGUA capitals seem to be built on the Gothic even width principle, using squared forms. The only unusual feature is the termination of the N diagonal in the middle of the right hand stroke rather than at the base. Another squared Gothic font with a similar, but less distinctive N is Big Noodle Titling

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710im_/http:/typophile.com/files/BigNoodleTitling_6264.jpg)
  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/sentinel/big-noodle-titling/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/sentinel/big-noodle-titling/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/sentinel/big-noodle-titling/")  
Unfortunately the A does not have angled sides.  
Don

Larger scale pix of the letters in the font:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710im_/http:/typophile.com/files/PANIAGUA_3579.jpg)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710im_/http:/typophile.com/files/BIANCHI_3473.jpg)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710im_/http:/typophile.com/files/FAEMA_5578.jpg)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710im_/http:/typophile.com/files/MOLTENI_5853.jpg)
  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710im_/http:/typophile.com/files/MOLTENI2_6389.jpg)
  
Note the rounded corners.  
Don

I knew I'd already seen it. Previous discussion [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/typophile.com/node/100407) but it was for "MOLTENI" lettering. Dick Pape suggested [Massiva GrotesQ](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/dawnland/massiva-grotesq) which actually works pretty well squooshed. Reminds me of many of [Jeff Levine](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.myfonts.com/foundry/Jeff_Levine/) fonts like [Canby](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/canby), [Lobby Card](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/lobby-card), [Deerfield](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/jnlevine/deerfield).  
Best chance is probably asking directly [Hello](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/www.01134.co.uk/studio/paniagua-a-fusion-of-cycling-design-food-and-coffee).

I knew I'd already seen it. Previous discussion [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20140715052710/http:/typophile.com/node/100407) but it was for "MOLTENI" lettering. Hi..

I'm in two minds as to wether to put you out of your misery.. and have the font used all over the shop.. or keep schtum ;).

I designed the logo, it is a font, with a special character... but I kinda like that it's unique at the moment - so may keep it under my hat.. bribes accepted though ;-)

Jamie
